inc. the software, called admc, automates active directory management tasks, such as deleting users or group accounts or changing the properties of active use. users can enforce naming conventions with admc and replace multiple manual steps <q> setting up user accounts with automated repeatable and standardized processes. it managers can also put in place review and approval processes for object creation and modification, according to the company. the technology is based on netpro's netcontrol services-oriented architecture. administrators need to download and install a front-end console, and an agent is installed on a domain controller. the user interface is an extension of the native active directory interface. </q> it administrators can define specific workflows and approval processes that need to be enforced behind the scenes before those changes are rolled into the production environment, "said brad hibbert, vice president of product strategy for phoenix,

state st., portsmouth first prize went to Patricia Elliott schappler for her acrylic painting titled an untraditional, urban landscape, this piece draws your eye to the bottom and into the background, the motion like water down drain, inevitably through the green light and down the street. reflective glass and familiar industrial shapes make this fun to look at. another favorite of mine was william scoleve's lino cut simply wrought fish and other things of the deep encroach on a lined notebook. though lino cuts and other simple methods of printing are by nature devoid of exact details, this print communicates well and gives hints of the process along with its evocative subject. and, as always, adeline goldminc-tronzo's piece held my attention. portrait of rachel in the nude "gains texture from its oil on linen. it's one of the larger pieces in the room, and goldminc-tronzo clearly makes her subject comfortable- the composition is imbued with a

heart, in heaven. the last supper was his wedding banquet prepared by our heavenly father; his words," this is my body, given for you... this is my blood, shed for you... <q> were his wedding vows... and the consummation of this wedding was his love unto death on the cross, but always in view of our resurrecting with him. it's non-physical eros at its best-- desire of union with one's spouse-- in this case, the church, which becomes one with him. </q>" yes, but i will have a broken heart, "he insisted, following her lead, but seeing if she would see the right meaning." it's freezing out! the iconic california company. apple said ipod division vice-president Tony Fadell and his wife, Danielle Lambert , who is vice-president of the company's human resources department, were to" devote more time to their young family. while the spotlight routinely shines on apple's notoriously involved chief executive Steve Jobs , mr Tony Fadell is said to be the one behind the idea for ipod mp3 players that rocketed to global success and revived the company's fortunes. Tony Fadell and dani have each made important contributions to apple over the past eight years, "mr Steve Jobs said in a statement." we're sorry to see dani go and are looking forward to working with Tony Fadell
